snippet: The rapidly expanding number of Japanese retirees benefit from the currency’s rise, but it has made the country’s exports expensive abroad.
abstract: Analysts say one big reason that Japan has done little to rein in the high yen, which makes the country's exports expensive abroad, is that the rapidly expanding number of Japanese retirees benefit from the currency's rise; inaction on the yen reflects a new political reality, with already indecisive leaders loath to upset retirees who make up more than 25 percent of the population and tend to vote in high numbers.
lead_paragraph: The rapidly expanding number of Japanese retirees benefit from the currency’s rise, but it has made the country’s exports expensive abroad.

headline.main: Strong Yen Is Dividing Generations in Japan
headline.print_headline: Strong Yen Is Dividing Generations in Japan
